text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 15th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns from work, he takes the elevator to the 10th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining five floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Alright, so I have this puzzle here about a man living on the 15th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, after work, he takes the elevator up to the 10th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining five floors to his apartment.
But here's the twist: on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor.

The question is, why does he do this on rainy days?

Okay, let me try to break this down.
First, I need to figure out why he changes his routine on rainy days.
Normally, he goes to the 10th floor and walks up five floors.
But on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor.

So, why would he do that?

Maybe it's something about the elevator itself.
Perhaps the elevator has a limit or a problem when it's raining.
Let me think.
If it's raining, maybe the elevator doesn't work properly, like it gets stuck or something.
But wait, if it's stuck, he wouldn't be able to go all the way up.
Or maybe the elevator is broken on rainy days, so he can't go up to the 10th floor.
But that doesn't make sense because on rainy days, he's taking it all the way to the 15th floor.
Wait, maybe the problem is with the stairs.
If it's raining, maybe the stairs are wet and slippery, so he doesn't want to walk up them.
That could be a reason.
So, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor instead of walking up the stairs because the stairs are too dangerous.
Alternatively, maybe the building has a rule against walking on the stairs in the rain.
Perhaps the management says that during rain, residents must take the elevator.
That could be another possibility.
Another angle: maybe the man is trying to save time or energy.
On normal days, he takes the elevator down in the morning and then in the evening, he takes the elevator up to the 10th floor and walks up.
But on rainy days, maybe the elevator is faster because he doesn't have to walk up five floors.
Or perhaps the elevator is quicker than walking, so he prefers that on rainy days.
Wait, but the problem says he takes the elevator to the 10th floor on normal days.
So, on rainy days, he's taking it all the way to the 15th floor.
So, perhaps it's not about speed or time.
It must be something about the stairs.
Let me think again.
On rainy days, the stairs might be slippery, so he doesn't feel safe walking up them.
Therefore, to avoid slipping, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor instead of walking up five floors.
Alternatively, maybe the man has a physical issue, like a bad back or mobility problem, making it hard for him to walk up stairs, especially when they're wet.
So, on rainy days, he chooses to take the elevator because walking is difficult.
But the problem doesn't mention anything about his physical condition, so it's probably not that.
It's more likely related to the environment or building rules.
So, considering all this, the most plausible reason is that on rainy days, the stairs are too slippery, making it dangerous to walk up them.
Therefore, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor to avoid slipping on the stairs.

</think>

The man takes the elevator to the 15th floor on rainy days because the stairs are slippery, making it unsafe to walk up them.
